div.head: Amaranth color
div.ab: Although it is said to be immortal, white wine removes its coloration and makes it light red and the dried flower ends up white. Note that wine does so, and I have tried it. Spirits have the same effect.

div.head: Drying of oil
div.ab: If the oil does not dry, put in massicot and minium. There is no better oil than walnut oil, because it does not dry out too quickly nor too slowly.

div.head: Casting
div.ab: The Germans use lead from Flanders because it is very soft. And to cast better they take lead ore & melt it, & separate what is melted from the from the filth & ore, & pour it into a separate vessel, then the bottom they cast with it. For the lead must not have been used in works before, but rather completely new. Some cast into molds of iron & copper.
left-middle or new lead coming from the mine. They melt it twice in a crucible. In the first one, they cleanse it of filth. In the second, they en cast.

div.head: Shadows
div.ab: German painters shade their flesh tones with crushed jet, stil de grain yellow and ochre.
It is only employed in distemper, and is used for the color of wood.

div.head: Verdigris and another very beautiful, gay green
div.ab: One must not crush it with water alone, because that makes it fade. To make it beautiful in distemper, some crush it with vinegar, but that makes it turn pale and become whitish. To make it beautiful, crush it with urine and leave it to dry. Then, whenever you like, crush it with oil. And after you have collected it with the palette, before you finish cleaning the marble, crush it there with stil de grain yellow. And you will have a very beautiful green.
